results.title: [Albert Drayton Home Movies: Reel 7]
results.brief_description:
This film follows on from the Drayton Family Movies: Reel 5

The film continues exploring events and scenes from Raboul in Papua New Guinea then continues to other villages.

There are many scenes of local people in costume providing performances and ceremonies for the tourists of the cruise ship.

There are a few scenes of missionary buildings and schools and many scenes of students in uniform. The student marching teams are seen doing regimented marching exercises.

Also seen are ruins and gravestones from early missionaries on the island.

Towards the end of the film a duk-duk dance is filmed. At the time it was an illegal dance to perform.

The film finishes at the arrival of another village in New Britain.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 – Young Chinese students, at the Overseas Chinese School, Raboul

00:00:09:00 – Harold Drayton, Mr Jefferies, Albert Drayton standing in a church doorway, Raboul

00:00:29:00 – Local Cemetery holding Australians soldiers killed in the First World War, Raboul

00:01:12:00 – Guards on Duty, Government House, Raboul

00:01:41:00 – Prisoners marching back to their cells after a day’s work, Raboul

00:01:51:00 – local costume and dance performance. George Brown College, Raboul

00:02:57:00 – College Boys in uniform marching, Raboul

00:03:22:00 – Harold Drayton, Mrs Drayton, Mr Drayton, Mrs Lowe, Mrs Hargraves part of the Sunshine cruise passengers drinking from coconuts

00:03:56:00 – Dance Performances and music, St George Browns College, Raboul

00:07:03:00 – George Brown College boys and girls, performing marching exercises, rhythm exercises with coconut shells and sticks, Raboul

00:09:40:00 – Passengers of the cruise on a hike with sun umbrellas, Raboul

00:09:56:00 – Man sitting on Tortoise as it tries to move, Raboul

00:11:12:00 – Cruise passengers posing with local men

00:11:14:00 – local man with spear and Axe

00:11:53:00 – local man performs a banned Duk-Duk-dance

00:13:45:00 – Farewelled by village locals, New Britain, boats point of view

00:14:26:00 – Arriving at a new village (unidentified) New Britain with local students in uniform and drums being played to welcome the tourists

results.title: [Albert Drayton Home Movies: Reel 6]
results.brief_description:
Much of this film contains scenes of landscape in Alice Springs including the Standley Chasm.

There are a few different modes of transport seen throughout such as a 1956 Austin Healey, the Ghan locomotive, a bus owned by the Tuit’s coach services and horses.

Also shown is the John Flynn Memorial Church and Adelaide House, Alice Springs, the first hospital which was created by John Flynn.

Of interest for Aboriginal heritage is a few scenes of local Aboriginal men working on a tractor and Aboriginal horsemen.

The film finishes with a scene of the Drayton Home in Melbourne.

Selected hightlights list:
00:00:02:00 - Train carriage carrying a 1956 Austin Healey 100

00:00:12:00 – Old Ghan locomotive at the Old Ghan Heritage Railway and Museum Alice Springs

00:00:38:00 - Alice Springs, John Flynn Memorial Uniting Church

00:00:51:00 - Adelaide House, Alice Springs

00:00:59:00 – Two Aboriginal men working on a tractor

00:02:25:00 – Passengers exiting the bus – Tuit’s Coach Services

00:03:49:00 – Anzac Hill Memorial lookout - Alice Springs

00:05:10:00 – Scenic – Rocky hills on the way towards Standley Chasm, Alice Springs

00:06:57:00 – Standley Chasm

00:10:21:00 – Unknown saleswoman in a shop

00:10:25:00 – Cattle yard with cattle coming off a train carriage with 1954 Ford Mainline Utility in view

00:10:47:00 – tourists taking photos of Aboriginal horsemen

00:13:50:00 – Scenic reflection in a Puddle

results.title: [Albert Drayton Home Movies: Reel 5]
results.brief_description:
This film follows the Drayton family on a Methodist missionary cruise to Papua New Guinea.

It begins in Sydney Harbour upon a passenger ship with a streamer farewell and continues with a visit to Stony Creek Falls and the Forest Gardens, Karunda before heading to Kwato and later Raboul, Papua New Guinea.

There are scenes of the Stony Creek train, bridge and falls as well as the Barron Falls.

In Kwato, there are many scenes of local men, women and children going about their daily activities including the making of Sago.

In Robaul, the tourists are treated to local celebration with music, costume and dance.

There a few scenes with boats, ships and canoes from Papa New Guinea including a canoe race.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 – Ship departure from Sydney dock with crowds and streamers

00:01:50:00 – Overflow Train and carriage Kuranda with Mr and Mrs Drayton and Ted Drayton

00:02:16:00 – Stony Creek Falls with tourists on the bridge and train. Stony Creek, Cairns

00:02:58:00 – Barron Falls, Cairns

00:03:34:00 – Mr and Mrs Drayton, unknown woman and Harold Drayton in the Rain Forest Gardens, Karanda

00:03:49:00 – Albert Drayton and sister Mavis in the Rain Forest Gardens, Karanda

00:06:18:00 – Jack Wallis, Mrs Drayton, Mr Webster and Mr Drayton, Kwato

00:06:23:00 – Mr Drayton with Local Men, Kwato

00:06:46:00 – locals making Sago, building a boat and weaving, Kwato

00:07:33:00 – Reverend Wesley Amos and son drinking from coconuts

00:07:52:00 – Mr and Mrs Drayton with a group of local kids singing, Kwato

00:08:37:00 – Mavis in canoe with two local men, Kwato

00:09:21:00 – Missionary Choir, Kwato

00:09:38:00 – Canoe Race - Kwato

00:10:01:00 – Albert Drayton and locals, Kwato

00:10:33:00 – Raboul, New Guinea showing the Mission House, a local policeman and locals dressed in tradition garments ready for performance

00:11:24:00 – Traditional dance and musicians playing percussion, Raboul

00:12:37:00 – Closeup of one of the headdresses, Raboul

00:12:59:00 – After ceremony, bringing of gifts members of the cruise including live birds on a stick. Raboul

results.title: The Youth who wanted to shiver
results.creator_credit: Bosustow Entertainment, Acton Films, Nick Bosustow, C B Wismar and Sam Weiss
results.brief_description: An animated adaptation of the classic fairy tale by the Brothers Grimm, about Jack who knows no fear and wants to be able to shiver. All help fails until his bride pours a bucket of tiny fish over him.

results.title: Fisherman & his wife: a Grimm's fairy tale
results.creator_credit: Bosustow Entertainment, Churchill Films, Nick Bosustow, C B Wismar and Sam Weiss
results.brief_description: A Grimm’s fairy tale about a humble fisherman who frees a prince from a spell. The fisherman’s wife siezes the opportunity to have all her wishes granted but ends up where she started, thus learning a bitter lesson.

results.title: Is it always right to be right?
results.creator_credit: Stephen Bosustow Productions, Nick Bosustow and Lee Mishkin
results.brief_description: This fast moving parable, designed to provoke discussion without alienating any group, highlights the centres of divisiveness in our society, the generation gap, poverty, war and race. It tells of a land “where men were always right”. This animated film is a winner of many awards including an Academy Award. Narrated by Orson Welles.

results.title: [William Dobell]
results.brief_description: On the tranquil shores of Lake Macquarie, William Dobell lives and works. He and Dame Mary Gilmore discuss his work and its development - rough sketches from real life later translated to danvas; commissioned portraits; and landscapes. Studies of some of his better known works are included. Contains some b&w footage.

results.title: Pandemonium
results.creator_credit: KFM Pandemonium, Smart Street Films, Tra La La Films and Haydn Keenan
results.brief_description: Haydn Keenan’s “Pandemonium” is a schlock horror movie that aims to displease by entertaining themes of Neo-Nazism, torture, vampirism, incest, sado-masochism, mental illness, necrophilia and bestiality. In the opening sequence Kales Leadingham has escaped from a lunatic asylum. Arriving at a bus stop be relays his travails (in flashback) to a woman seated there. One day at Bondi Beach, Sydney, a woman ‘Dingo Girl’ arrives in search of answers to her past (cue unremitting shots of Dingo Girl’s large breasts, a la Russ Meyer). Shortly after Dingo Girl and Kale enter a warehouse where a bizarre array of subversive types reside. Inhabitants engage in ritualistic Neo-Nazi ceremonies that result in sado-masochistic sex. Amid other activities, a foetus is placed in a blender, Little Adolph has his penis cut off, cloning experiments go awry - whilst numerous musical interludes interrupt the action. Deliberately provocative, and seeking to shock, this film revels in its low-budget amateurism and artlessness. Aesthetically it shares much in common with “Flesh for Frankenstein” and “Rocky Horror Picture Show” but has no hope of achieving the cult status of these enduring films, principally because its relentlessly over-the-top mood and delivery rob it of any impact as comedy or as horror. The unremitting black humour, shoddy sets, trashy costuming, bad taste themes and poor acting, make “Pandemonium” a curio of Australian filmmaking. Cast includes David Argue, Amanda Dole, Esben Storm, Ian Nimmo, Gary Foley, Haydn Keenan, Ignatius Jones, Lex Marinos.
results.creator_credit_for_label: KFM Pandemonium, Smart Street Films, Tra La La Films and Haydn Keenan
results.description: Haydn Keenan’s “Pandemonium” is a schlock horror movie that aims to displease by entertaining themes of Neo-Nazism, torture, vampirism, incest, sado-masochism, mental illness, necrophilia and bestiality. In the opening sequence Kales Leadingham has escaped from a lunatic asylum. Arriving at a bus stop be relays his travails (in flashback) to a woman seated there. One day at Bondi Beach, Sydney, a woman ‘Dingo Girl’ arrives in search of answers to her past (cue unremitting shots of Dingo Girl’s large breasts, a la Russ Meyer). Shortly after Dingo Girl and Kale enter a warehouse where a bizarre array of subversive types reside. Inhabitants engage in ritualistic Neo-Nazi ceremonies that result in sado-masochistic sex. Amid other activities, a foetus is placed in a blender, Little Adolph has his penis cut off, cloning experiments go awry - whilst numerous musical interludes interrupt the action. Deliberately provocative, and seeking to shock, this film revels in its low-budget amateurism and artlessness. Aesthetically it shares much in common with “Flesh for Frankenstein” and “Rocky Horror Picture Show” but has no hope of achieving the cult status of these enduring films, principally because its relentlessly over-the-top mood and delivery rob it of any impact as comedy or as horror. The unremitting black humour, shoddy sets, trashy costuming, bad taste themes and poor acting, make “Pandemonium” a curio of Australian filmmaking. Cast includes David Argue, Amanda Dole, Esben Storm, Ian Nimmo, Gary Foley, Haydn Keenan, Ignatius Jones, Lex Marinos.
